stage.stage: The play takes place in MRS. WARREN 'S little living room during the early Victorian period . At the left is a door leading to another part of the house . A door at the back opens into the entrance hall . As the curtain rises , MRS. WARREN , seated in a large chair , is talking to her maid , CLARA .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Gossip is malicious , my dear girl , positively malicious . Does n't the Bible say —The knocker sounds .There , is n't that the door ?CLARA starts to go .Oh , Clara , before you open the door , be sure and dust off the table in the hall and ——

body.stage: CLARA goes out . MRS. WARREN arranges her dress and the little lace cap on her head .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: From the doorIt 's Mrs. Lawty , ma'am .

lg.l: Oh , the dear soul ! Have her come right in — right in ,
Clara .

body.stage: CLARA goes out . MRS. LAWTY enters .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Good afternoon — good afternoon , Mrs. Warren .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Good afternoon , my dear . Do sit down , Mrs. Lawty — do sit down .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Oh , thank you . I have just dropped in for a moment . I am on my way to the meeting of the “ Helping Hand Society , ” and as I had to pass this way I just came in to see how you were . I hope I am not interrupting any work you may be doing , my dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh , dear , no . I was just giving my maid a little lecture ... on gossip .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Gossip ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: It is so malicious .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Positively unladylike ! One could almost compare a lady who gossips to a ... to a pirate .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: A what , Mrs. Lawty ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: A pirate . They are sort of wild thieves , you know , and steal things from perfectly innocent people , Mrs. Warren . The South Sea Islands are full of them ... pirates , I mean . Why , I read in our missionary paper , just last week , that one poor man was overtaken by pirates who took away his watch and , I hesitate to say it , his trousers !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: His trousers ! Dreadful !

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: The rest of the story is too indelicate to repeat .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes ... yes , some things are often better left unsaid .Pause .But one need never be ashamed to speak the truth . What is the rest of the story , Mrs. Lawty ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: The poor man was forced to come into port with a bad cold in his head ... and in his pajamas !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: And that is why I call a woman who gossips a pirate .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes ... yes . Though one can hardly think of any woman unlawfully taking a poor gentleman 's trousers .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Hardly . But to steal one 's good name is to take one 's cloak of righteousness , so to speak . And , oh , my dear , few people can face the world without it . The soul is so much more important than the body .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: One should keep both properly clothed .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Yes ... though on the South Sea Islands the people wear nothing but grass skirts .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: One could hardly do that in England .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Oh , but the people there , in the South Seas , are like little children ... pure of mind . And so it is one of the very first rules of the “ Helping Hand Society ” that no gossip shall pass our lips .

lg.l: Such a worthy organization . I am sure the ladies of
Northampton are doing a noble work .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Oh , yes , indeed , Mrs. Warren . Why , only last week we sent off a large box of soap to the natives of East Africa and now we are getting a box of napkins and tablecloths ready . We are doing such splendid work for our less fortunate brothers and sisters in a far land .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Brothers and sisters ! One hardly feels that way toward them , Mrs. Lawty . I am told they are quite black .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Nevertheless they are Gaud 's creatures .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: My dear , I shall have Clara make you a hot cup of tea . It will rest you .She callsClara ... Clara !

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Oh , no , thank you ... really . I must n't stop . I always like to get to the society meetings early ... otherwise one misses so much that is interesting .She rises .

body.stage: CLARA appears .

lg.l: Never mind , Clara .
Oh , Clara ,
Clara ——

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Clara , will you put the water on to boil ? And make the tea rather strong ... but not too strong ... just so .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .She goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: By the way , have you met the new doctor and his wife , Mrs. Warren ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes , I have called on Mrs. Hunter .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: She sits down againOh , really ? How interesting .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: But , of course , Betty knows both of them . I must call on Mrs. Hunter again . But I get out so seldom now ... so seldom . I am so afraid to walk on the new ... pavement , I believe they call it . Betty is very fond of them both ... the Hunters , I mean .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Quite ... though Mrs. Romney told Mrs. Pickering who told me that the Hunters did not get along well together . It seems she is a Church of England woman while the doctor is the son of a Scotch Presbyterian , so of course ——

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Though I believe they have been married all of five or six years .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Oh , really , I did not know that . How interesting ! I must tell Mrs. Romney . But Mrs. Lawer told me that the doctor calls Mrs. Hunter “ Dearest ” ... in public !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Such poor taste .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: I always suspect a man who is over-demonstrative ... in public .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: But of course one ——

body.stage: BETTY comes running in , her arms full of daisies .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Mother dear —— Oh , good afternoon , Mrs. Lawty . See the wonderful flowers Doctor Hunter just gave me .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Doctor Hunter gave you those ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Doctor Hunter !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Yes , his garden is full of them ! Are n't they beauties ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: But you hardly know him well enough to ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: You see we are getting acquainted . He was on his way to see Mrs. Hallway and ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Is she ill again ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Rheumatism ... not really serious .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Oh , really ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: And as the doctor was coming this way , he walked to the gate with me ... we had a lovely chat . Doctor Hunter is such an interesting conversationalist .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: ColdlyWalking ! Has n't he a carriage ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Oh , yes , but it is such a wonderful day for walking .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: I daresay that all depends upon with whom one is walking .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Betty , you do n't really mean to tell me that you walked ... walked down a public highway with a strange man !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Why , Mother , he is n't a strange man . I know both Doctor and Mrs. Hunter .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: But such a short acquaintance ... and to be walking with him ... walking with him in broad daylight .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: What would you have me do ? Walk with him after dark ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: When she recovers her breathI — I really must be going , Mrs. Warren . I must not be late to the meeting , you know .She pauses .And perhaps you would rather be alone with your daughter at this time .She rises .Good afternoon , Mrs. Warren . Good afternoon .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Good afternoon , Mrs. Lawty .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Good-bye .

body.stage: MRS. LAWTY goes out . MRS. WARREN waits until the front door slams before she speaks .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Much concernedBetty , how could you ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: But , Mother ——

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Walking with a man , a man who is married and not on the best terms with his wife , accepting flowers from him , a Presbyterian , unchaperoned . Oh ! It is so unbecoming ... so — so unladylike , not to say indiscreet . Oh ! Why , when I was a girl ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: I know .She goes close to her mother .But things have changed so since then , dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Not in Northampton , thank heaven . Here , at least , we still keep some of the old propriety . Oh , Betty , this bold indiscretion of yours would have killed your poor , dear father !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Turning awayPerhaps that 's what did ... too much propriety .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Did you say something , Betty ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: I am sorry , dear ... truly sorry if I have caused you any anxiety .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: We must cultivate the doctor 's wife at once . There must be no room for gossip among the ladies of Northampton .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Cultivate Mrs. Hunter ? Oh , I would love to . She is a delightful person . Do n't you like her , Mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: She seems very nice , but , of course , one must be very careful about strangers .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: She is very fond of outdoor life , and all that sort of thing . Oh , she is a regular sport !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Betty ! Let me never hear such a remark from you again . Sport ! Am I to understand , then ... am I to understand that Mrs. Hunter is one of those dreadful mannish sort of persons who ——The knocker sounds .Oh , dear me ! I wonder who that can be ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: If you do n't mind , Mother , I shall go up to my room . I want to do a water-color sketch of these flowers while they are still fresh .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Stop here a bit , Betty .

body.stage: CLARA enters from the hall .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: It is Mrs. Romney , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh , do have her come right in , Clara ... and Clara , serve the tea at once .CLARA goes out .Mrs. Romney — oh , dear ... such a bombastic sort of a person , so to speak .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: She was educated in London , you know .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes , poor dear , she has so much to live down . It must be dreadful to have been educated in London ... such a naughty place . Think of the dreadful environment , my dear , London !

body.stage: MRS. ROMNEY enters .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Good afternoon , Mrs. Warren . How do you do , Betty , dear ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Do sit down , Mrs. Romney .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Did I hear you speaking of London as I came in , Mrs. Warren ?

lg.l: London ? Speaking of London ? Were we speaking of London ,
Betty ? Yes , I believe I did say ——

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Dear old London ... how I long for it !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: But my dear Mrs. Romney , London surely has n't the ... the refinement of Northampton .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Northampton ! Ah ! Why , this place is as far from the world as ... as the South Sea Islands !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Mrs. Romney , how — how can you even think such a thing ? Why , in the South Sea Islands , I am told , the people wear nothing but straw skirts ... and pirates , pirates take things — unmentionable things from innocent travelers . One could not accuse the people of Northampton of such things . Even our shop-keepers are gentlemen compared to those dreadful people who live in the South Seas .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: The people of the South Sea Islands are at least — interesting .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Perfect savages !

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: But , my dear , all our forefathers were savages , you know ... hitting each other over the head with clubs , hanging from palm trees by their tails , and all that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh , dear !

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: And the longer I live in Northampton , my dear , the more I 'm convinced that it was n't so very many generations ago , either .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh ... oh ... oh ! Betty , you may go ! You will excuse the dear child , I am sure . She has duties to perform which ——

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Oh , yes , certainly .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: She rises and collects her flowersGood afternoon , Mrs. Romney . Shall I see you at Mrs. Hunter 's tea Thursday ?

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Yes , dear , charmed .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Good-bye .

body.stage: MRS. ROMNEY bows . BETTY goes out left . CLARA enters with the tea things .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: You will have a cup of tea , Mrs. Romney ?

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Yes , thank you so much . So refreshing , nothing like tea for nerves , is there , really ? Half a cup ... I have just come from Mrs. Hunter 's . Both cream and sugar , yes , thank you so much . Such a charming lady , Mrs. Hunter ... perfectly charming , my dear , perfectly charming . So witty , so clever , so vivacious ... but dreadfully jealous .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Jealous ? Jealous of whom ?

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: She is very fond of her husband .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: NervouslyOf whom ... of whom is she jealous ?

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: No one in particular , at present , I think .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: With a sigh of reliefOh ——

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: That is ... oh , is there any cause for her being jealous of any particular person , Mrs. Warren ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Choking on her teaEh ? No ... no ... not that I know of .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: How uninteresting . The doctor is such a charming gentleman . Dear me , I do hope I will have another attack of indigestion , or something of that sort soon . I am sure Doctor Hunter would be such a splendid physician ... he is so good looking .She puts down her teacup .Dear me , I must be going . I am on my way to the meeting of the “ Helping Hand Society ” and ——

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes , Mrs. Lawty has just gone . She dropped in to see me for a moment .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Mrs. Lawty ... that one ? I 'm not speaking to her .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh , dear , you ... you do n't really mean you have quarrelled ? So unladylike .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Ladylike ... ladylike ? Ladylike be damned !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Almost jumping out of her chairMrs. Romney !

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Mrs. Warren , I beg your pardon . I forgot , for a moment , to whom I was speaking .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: That was quite evident .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Quite . But you see , Mrs. Lawty told Mrs. Pickering , who told Mrs. Lawer , who told Lady Bloshire , whose maid told my maid , that Mrs. Lawty said that I dyed my hair ... dyed my hair !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Really ?

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: I 've never dyed my hair . The impertinent gossip . The ——

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: QuicklyDo have another cup of tea , Mrs. Romney . It is so soothing .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Oh , thank you . Just a little sugar , please , and no cream .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Giving her the teaThere , my dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Lovely color , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes , is n't it ? Mr. Warren , dear man , once told me that the natives of India use tea for dyeing .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Hair ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: No ... no ... cloth , I believe , cloth .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Oh , how interesting !

lg.l: I believe they use the henna berry for dyeing hair in the
East . I am told it gives a beautiful soft auburn shade .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: How interesting . Does one procure it from one 's pharmacist ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Eh ? Oh , yes , I believe so .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: I must try it on my hair — oh , dear , I mean ——

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: What did you say , Mrs. Romney ?

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: I said — I really must be going , my dear . One never seems to realize how fast the time goes when one talks with you . Our little visit has been most interesting ... and most instructive . I do want to stop in for a moment and see Mrs. Hallway before I go to the meeting of the “ Helping Hand . ” Her rheumatism is worse again , poor dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes , so I heard . I 'm so sorry .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Oh , it is not at all serious , just a touch , I believe . Of course she did call in Doctor Hunter . But I really believe it was simply to get acquainted with him more than anything else .She starts .Do drop in and see me when you can . Good afternoon , Mrs. Warren .She goes out .

body.stage: CLARA enters .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Shall I take away the tea things , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: No ... no , not just yet , Clara . Someone else may drop in , you know , and perhaps Betty would like a cup of tea .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Shall I call her , ma'am ?

lg.l: Yes , I believe you had bet ——
There , there , see who that is , Clara .

body.stage: CLARA goes into the hall . She returns immediately .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: It 's Mrs. Pickering , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Have her come right in , Clara .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Shall I call Miss Betty , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes , do have her come down and have a cup of tea .

body.stage: CLARA goes out . MRS. PICKERING enters .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: How do you do , Mrs. Warren ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh , good afternoon . Do sit down , Mrs. Pickering .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: Oh ... my dear Mrs. Warren , I am so glad to see you looking so well . I thought perhaps — of course there is much sickness in Northampton now .She sits down .Much sickness .Pause .I just met Mrs. Lawty and she told me that Mrs. Hallway is almost dead with rheumatism ... almost dead . In fact , I think they hardly expect her to live much longer . Of course , Mrs. Lawty did n't say so , but I implied as much from the tone of her voice .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: I heard it was nothing really serious .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: Oh , dear , yes ... very serious . I just had it from Mrs. Lawty , who had it from ... from ... from a most reliable source . Rheumatism is such a painful death , too . Oh , dear , poor soul ... poor soul !MRS. WARREN hands her a cup of tea .Thank you so much .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: I believe the new Doctor Hunter is attending her .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: Yes , is n't it too bad ? Mrs. Lawty tells me he is a conversationalist , or something dreadful of that sort . But of course he was educated in London ... and , my dear , London 's standard of morals is not the same as Northampton 's . I was also told that he treats his wife very badly in public , my dear , in public .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: You mean ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Warren , I am very sorry to tell you ... but I feel that it is my duty , as wife of your pastor ... to tell you that your daughter Betty has been seen very often ,— that is , at least once — walking with this Doctor Hunter . Also , my dear Mrs. Warren , she accepts presents from him ... flowers and that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Why , Betty hardly knows him !

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: That is just it . She hardly knows him ... nor do any of us . Also remember he is a married man , my dear Mrs. Warren , and very good looking ... and I really believe all good-looking people are bad , thoroughly bad .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: I can n't believe that Betty ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: Naturally , my dear , naturally ; you are her mother and wish to shield her . But I felt that it was , as I said before , my duty to tell you all I know of the facts of the whole matter .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: You quite alarm me , Mrs. Pickering .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: Young girls , nowadays , are sometimes ... I might say , sometimes indiscreet .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: My dear , men are strange beings . Oh , the poor souls that have been lured to their destruction by men . I am always reminded of that beautiful passage in Genesis which says that woman was made after man . And is n't it our dear Mr. Browning who says , “ Second thoughts are always best ” ?She puts down her teacup .There , now , I really must be going , Mrs. Warren . I am on my way to the meeting of the “ Helping Hand Society ” and I really must n't be too late . I hope I have not overly alarmed you , Mrs. Warren , but as one of your oldest friends and as the wife of your pastor I feel that I must always do my duty , no matter how painful , when the way lies open before me . I sincerely hope you will not feel that I have been ... been peremptory , so to speak , Mrs. Warren .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: No ... no . It is very kind of you to come to me in this sad moment of trouble .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: RisingI do hope you will be able to attend the services to-morrow morning . Mr. Pickering has written a beautiful sermon on the evils of gossip ... a beautiful sermon . I feel that it is the best thing he has written in all the forty years of his righteous work . I am sure it will thunder down the ages as his masterpiece . The sentiment , the beautiful English , and even the punctuation ... are really marvelous . Of course , Mr. Pickering and I both realize that there is very little gossip in Northampton ... but it is best to know sin when one encounters it . Good afternoon , Mrs. Warren .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: WeaklyGood afternoon .

body.stage: MRS. PICKERING goes out . CLARA enters .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I have brought the hot water , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Did you call Betty ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I knocked at her door , ma'am ... I knocked very loudly , ma'am , but got no answer .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: I am so distressed , Clara . See if she is in the garden . Yes , she must be in the garden .CLARA starts .And Clara , do tell her to come in and see me at once . I want to talk to her . It is very important ... oh , most important that I see her at once . Clara .The knocker sounds .See who that can be , Clara . Oh , more dreadful news , I fear .CLARA goes into the hall . MRS. WARREN keeps mumbling to herself :Most disconcerting ... most dreadfully disconcerting .

body.stage: CLARA enters .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: It is Mrs. Lawer , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Eh ? What ? Who , did you say ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Mrs. Lawer , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Mrs. Lawer ? Oh , do have her come right in , Clara .

body.stage: CLARA goes out . MRS. LAWER enters .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: Good afternoon , Mrs. Warren , good afternoon .BreathlesslyHow ill , how worried you are looking , Mrs. Warren . Oh , I am so sorry for you ... so very sorry .She sits down .I have just seen Mrs. Romney , who had just seen Mrs. Lawty , and had the dreadful news from her . I am so sorry , Mrs. Warren .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: But what ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: But , of course , we who have known you for all these years will be as silent as the tomb ... you can depend upon us , lean upon us , call upon us . We shall comfort you and be your support in this hour of greatest need .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Why ... why , what do you mean ?

lg.l: You really mean to say you do not know about Betty and
Doctor Hunter ? Oh , dear !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: But Betty did nothing so very , very improper .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: Improper ! Well , of course , we shall not blame poor Betty , she is still very young , but we do blame that wicked Doctor Hunter . Why , he is a married man , my dear ... and oldish . He should have known better .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: But Betty only walked with him .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: Only walked with him ? I was told that he sends flowers to Betty ... and flowers have secret meanings . To say the least , they are sentimental . And Mrs. Lawty told Mrs. Romney that she heard Betty say with her own lips that Doctor Hunter was a conversationalist . I believe that means a person with very free ideas about personal matters ... love , and that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: No , indeed ... it simply means that he is a very interesting talker .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: That 's just it , Mrs. Warren . What does he find so much to talk about ? I have never met him , but from things I have heard I believe he must be a dreadful person . Most unwholesome , so to speak , to the society — the very refined society of Northampton , where for the last forty years we have all lived in such perfect peace and understanding .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh , that this should have come upon me !

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: Your misfortune is our misfortune , Mrs. Warren . We shall do everything we can to keep this dreadful scandal ——

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Scandal ! Has it — has it gone as far as that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: Let us say , indiscretion . As I was saying , we shall keep it locked in our hearts , no word of it will ever reach foreign ears . Of course I really know very little of the whole affair , but I felt that my first duty was to come to you .

body.stage: CLARA enters .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes , Clara ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I can n't find her , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh , do find her , Clara . I must ... I must see her at once .The knocker sounds .Who can that be ? Clara ... Clara , see who is at the door .

body.stage: CLARA goes out .

lg.l: Oh , Mrs. Warren , trust me in everything ... are you sure
Betty has always been what she seemed ... I mean ——

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Mrs. Lawer , do you mean to say that Betty ... Betty Warren ... my daughter ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: My dear , we must face the truth ... we must prepare ourselves for the worst ... we must ——

body.stage: CLARA enters .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: It 's them “ Helpin ’ Hand ” ladies , if you please , ma'am . The lot of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Bring them in , Clara ... have them come right in . Oh ! Oh !

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: You must be calm , my dear ... perfectly calm .

body.stage: MRS. LAWTY , MRS. PICKERING , and MRS. ROMNEY enter from the hall .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh , my dear ladies . Do ... do be seated .

body.stage: They all sit down quietly . There is a long pause . MRS. PICKERING moves restlessly .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: Mrs. Warren , we have adjourned our meeting of the “ Helping Hand ” until next week in order to come to you ... the poor , dear natives of the South Sea Islands will have to wait another week for their napkins and tablecloths .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: A very short time ... considering they have not had such necessary luxuries for several centuries .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Still , it was with some feeling of ... of regret that we left our work of altruism unfinished , until next week .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: But we feel that our first duty is at home . Yes , we all felt that our duty was toward you , Mrs. Warren , at present .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Ladies , I am overcome with your kindness .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: We shall now consider ... consider ways and means of — of helping you , Mrs. Warren , out of this unspeakable — or , let us say , embarrassing situation .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Let us rather call it ... unfortunate situation .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: No matter what we call it ... let us get on ——

lg.l: The facts are these : Mrs. Lawty tells us she heard
Betty , with her own ears , openly say that the man under consideration ,
Doctor Hunter , was a revolutionist and ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: I said conversationalist . Though he probably is both .

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: I think she must have meant conventionalist .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: Nevertheless , one is as bad as the other . They all go hand in hand .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: But I believe Betty only said he was a good conversationalist and ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Anyway , she said he talked a lot about it .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: I fear it must be one of those dreadful , sinful new religions one hears so much of nowadays .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Also , we understand from very reliable sources that Mrs. Hunter is never seen with her husband in public .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: And that he calls her dreadful names .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Most suspicious !

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Oh , I do n't believe a word of it .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Believe it or not , Mrs. Romney ... my information is most reliable .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Is there any way , ladies , of overcoming this situation , I mean ——

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: You might call on Mrs. Hunter to-morrow , Mrs. Warren .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Never !

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: You might write her a very formal letter , very formal , my dear , asking her to call .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: Ask Mrs. Hunter to come here ? I think she would never set her foot in the house .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: At any rate , we must do something at once before ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Before they elope .

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: They all begin to talk at onceBefore it is too late . Oh ! Ah ! But do you really think — I never thought of that . Poor Mrs. Warren ! Do you suppose that Mrs. Hunter —— Oh ! Etc .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Ladies ! Ladies ! Do you really think Betty would ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: One never knows what to think !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Clara ! Clara !

body.stage: CLARA enters from the hall . She holds a letter in her hand .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Did you find Betty ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: I went to her room again , ma'am , but she did not seem to be in and she is nowhere in the garden .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: Not in her room ! Not in the garden !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: You mean , Clara , she is nowhere to be found ? Clara , was her room disturbed ... I mean , did it look as if ... as if ... as if she might have left hurriedly ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Why , I did n't go in , ma'am . The door was locked .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Locked ?

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: Looking at each other knowinglyLocked !

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Here is a note , ma'am . It was just left by Doctor Hunter 's boy , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: A letter !

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: From Doctor Hunter !

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Perhaps they have eloped !

body.stage: The ladies jump to their feet .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: And her room locked ... she must have gone through the window !

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: Gone !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Who has been too busy looking for her spectacles to notice what has been going on about herWhy , it is a letter for ——She looks up .Ladies , what is the matter ? What has happened ? Why are you all so excited ?

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: Do n't you understand ? It is a letter from Doctor Hunter saying they have eloped !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Sinking deep into her chairOh !

body.stage: BETTY appears in the door at left .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Ladies .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Waving the letter weaklyBetty ! Betty ! Betty !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Looking upBetty ... Betty , is that you ?

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Why are you all so — excited ? Mother , what is it ?

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: Oh !They all sit down again .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Then you — then you —— Oh , where have you been ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Why , just taking a little nap , Mother . Really , I did n't know the ladies were here or I should have come right down .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Then you have n't ... you have n't eloped ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Why , Mother dear , what do you mean ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: These ladies said — said ——

body.stage: The ladies all begin to talk at once .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: You see , Betty dear , Mrs. Pickering told Mrs. Romney , who told me that ——

lg.l: I did n't ! Nothing of the sort , Betty ! It was you yourself ,
Mrs. Lawty , who told Mrs. Pickering , who told ——

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: Me ? I had nothing at all to do with it ... nothing at all . I only know that Mrs. Lawer said ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: I said ? I said nothing . It was Mrs. Lawty , who told Mrs. Pickering , who told Mrs. Romney — oh , dear me , I mean ——

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: It 's a damn lie !

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: They all gasp for breath ; all begin to talk at onceI heard that Doctor Hunter — You told me that he treated his wife shamefully — No , I said — Flowers , he sent her flowers every morning — You told Mrs. Pickering that he was a conversationalist — She said a revolutionist — I said — You said — And then she said — Anyway , I do not believe he is a safe person . But very good looking , my dear . Etc .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Oh , dear ... what is it all about ?

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: You , my dear , you .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: These ladies said that you ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: These ladies !

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: They all begin to talk at once againWhy , it was she herself who said — I had nothing to do with it at all — All I know about the whole affair is that — The impertinence of her saying — I did n't say a word about —— Etc .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: It was all of them ... every one of them . They said you had — oh , dear , I just can n't say it ! They came here to tell me you had eloped with ... with a married man ... with Doctor Hunter !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Ladies ! Mother ! How dare you !She runs to her mother .How dare you say such a thing !To her motherMy poor , dear Mother !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: And it is so untrue . Oh ! Clara ... Clara ! My smelling-salts ... my smelling-salts ! I 'm going to faint ... I 'm going to faint ... I 'm going to faint !

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Running to MRS. WARRENHere , use mine , my dear , use mine .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: But the letter , Mrs. Warren .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: She has been fanning herself furiously with the letter . She suddenly holds it up as if it might be a bomb ready to go off in her hand .The letter ! Oh ! Take it ... take it ... take it away !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Taking the letterWhy , it is a note from ——

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: On the very edges of their chairsYes ?

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: From Mrs. Hunter .

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: Oh .They watch BETTY curiously as she reads the note .

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: Mother , Mrs. Hunter asks if I might go for a carriage drive with her this afternoon to gather wild flowers . She is going to stop for me . She says the doctor told her how very fond I am of flowers .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: With a great sigh of reliefOh !

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: May I go ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Why , yes , dear , if you think ——

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: I fear these ladies were quite mistaken about ——

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: These ladies , indeed ! Do you not include yourself ,— that is to say , are you not one of us ?

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: God forbid !

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: Oh !

body.stage: The knocker sounds .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Clara ... Clara !

body.stage: CLARA enters from the Left .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Did you call me , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Clara , there is someone at the door .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Very well , ma'am .She goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: I am sure Mrs. Warren will forgive our very grave mistake . But it was for her sake that ——

sp.speaker: BETTY
sp.p: How could you ever dream of worrying my dear mother by such scandalous gossip ? It is shameful !

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Betty ... Betty !

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: You , my dear , are still too young to understand .

body.stage: CLARA enters .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: I fear we were overquick in our judgment .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes , Clara ?

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: It is Mrs. Hunter , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Mrs. Hunter ? Do have her come right in , Clara .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Yes , ma'am . Shall I bring more tea , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Yes , Clara ... and cake , Clara .

sp.speaker: CLARA
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .She goes out .

sp.speaker: LADIES
sp.p: Oh , shall we stay ? Or shall we go ? It might be embarrassing — I am sure Mrs. Hunter ——

sp.speaker: MRS. ROMNEY
sp.p: Such an interesting person ... Mrs. Hunter .

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWTY
sp.p: I am so glad she and her husband have come to live with us here in Northampton .

sp.speaker: MRS. PICKERING
sp.p: We must ask her to join the “ Helping Hand Society . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. LAWER
sp.p: I am sure she will have so many good ideas .

sp.speaker: MRS. WARREN
sp.p: Ladies , I am so glad you are all here this afternoon ... so pleased .The ladies very properly arrange their dresses and bonnets as the curtain falls .The Touch-Down A comedy in four acts , by Marion Short . 8 males , 6 females , but any number of characters can be introduced in the ensembles . Costumes modern . One interior scene throughout the play . Time , 2-1 / 2 hours . This play , written for the use of clever amateurs , is the story of life in Siddell , a Pennsylvania co-educational college . It deals with the vicissitudes and final triumph of the Siddell Football Eleven , and the humorous and dramatic incidents connected therewith . “ The Touch-Down ” has the true varsity atmosphere , college songs are sung , and the piece is lively and entertaining throughout . High schools will make no mistake in producing this play . We strongly recommend it as a high-class and well-written comedy . Price , 30 Cents . Hurry , Hurry , Hurry A comedy in three acts , by LeRoy Arnold . 5 males , 4 females . One interior scene . Costumes modern . Plays 2-1 / 4 hours . The story is based on the will of an eccentric aunt . It stipulates that her pretty niece must be affianced before she is twenty-one , and married to her fiance within a year , if she is to get her spinster relative 's million . Father has nice notions of honor and fails to tell daughter about the will , so that she may make her choice untrammeled by any other consideration than that of true love . The action all takes place in the evening the midnight of which will see her reach twenty-one . Time is therefore short , and it is hurry , hurry , hurry , if she is to become engaged and thus save her father from impending bankruptcy . The situations are intrinsically funny and the dialogue is sprightly . The characters are natural and unaffected and the action moves with a snap such as should be expected from its title . Price , 30 Cents . The Varsity Coach A three-act play of college life , by Marion Short , specially adapted to performance by amateurs or high school students . 5 males , 6 females , but any number of boys and girls may be introduced in the action of the play . Two settings necessary , a college boy 's room and the university campus . Time , about 2 hours . Like many another college boy , “ Bob ” Selby , an all-round popular college man , becomes possessed of the idea that athletic prowess is more to be desired than scholarship . He is surprised in the midst of a “ spread ” in his room in Regatta week by a visit from his aunt who is putting him through college . Aunt Serena , “ a lady of the old school and the dearest little woman in the whole world , ” has hastened to make this visit to her adored nephew under the mistaken impression that he is about to receive the Fellowes prize for scholarship . Her grief and chagrin when she learns that instead of the prize Robert has received “ a pink card , ” which is equivalent to suspension for poor scholarship , gives a touch of pathos to an otherwise jolly comedy of college life . How the repentant Robert more than redeems himself , carries off honors at the last , and in the end wins Ruth , the faithful little sweetheart of the “ Prom ” and the classroom , makes a story of dramatic interest and brings out very clearly certain phases of modern college life . There are several opportunities for the introduction of college songs and “ stunts . ” Price , 30 Cents .The Above Are Subject to Royalty When ProducedSAMUEL FRENCH , 28-30 West 38th Street , New York City New and Explicit Descriptive Catalogue Mailed Free on Request The following is a list of changes made to the original .
